Vercel Deployment Error Solutions

Fixing common issues when deploying to Vercel

Error 1: Permission Denied (Exit Code 126)

Running "npm run build" > laundryfr@0.0.0 build > vite build sh: line 1: /vercel/path0/node_modules/.bin/vite: Permission denied Error: Command "npm run build" exited with 126

What this means:

The Vercel build environment doesn't have execute permissions for the Vite binary, usually due to permission issues in your node_modules.

Solutions:

1 Fix file permissions locally: 
rm -rf node_modules package-lock.json
npm install

Never use sudo with npm install as it causes permission issues.

2 Ensure Vite is a local dependency:

Check your package.json has Vite in devDependencies:

{
  "devDependencies": {
    "vite": "^5.0.0"
  }
}
3 Verify build script:

Ensure your package.json has the correct build script:

{
  "scripts": {
    "build": "vite build"
  }
}
4 Clear Vercel build cache:

In Vercel dashboard, redeploy and uncheck "Use existing build cache".

ℹ️ The "125 packages looking for funding" message is just informational and not related to the error.

Error 2: 404 Resource Not Found

(index):1 Failed to load resource: the server responded with a status of 404 ()

What this means:

The browser is trying to load a file (JS, CSS, image) that doesn't exist at the specified path on the server.

Solutions:

1 Check file paths in HTML:

Ensure paths in src and href attributes are correct:

<!-- Correct -->
<link href="/css/main.css" rel="stylesheet">

<!-- Incorrect -->
<link href="../public/css/main.css" rel="stylesheet">
2 Verify static file serving:

If using Express.js, ensure proper static file configuration:

app.use(express.static(__dirname + '/public'));
3 Check case sensitivity:

Linux servers (like Vercel) are case-sensitive. Ensure file cases match exactly.

4 Verify build output directory:

Check your framework configuration (vite.config.js) for correct output directory:

// vite.config.js
export default defineConfig({
  build: {
    outDir: 'dist',
  },
})
5 Use Network tab for debugging:

Open browser DevTools → Network tab to see which specific resource is returning 404.

⚠️ Always test your build locally with npm run build && npm run preview before deploying.

Preventive Measures

For future deployments:

1 Proper .gitignore:

Ensure node_modules is in your .gitignore file:

node_modules/
.env
.DS_Store
dist/
build/
2 Specify Node.js version:

Add engines field to package.json:

{
  "engines": {
    "node": "18.x"
  }
}
3 Test builds locally:

Always run npm run build locally before deploying to catch issues early.

4 Use Vercel CLI for testing:

Test with Vercel CLI to simulate deployment environment:

npm i -g vercel
vercel build
✅ Following these steps should resolve most Vercel deployment issues.

Need More Help?

Additional Resources:

1 Vercel Documentation:

Comprehensive guides for troubleshooting deployment issues.

https://vercel.com/docs

2 Vercel Community:

Ask questions and get help from other developers.

Vercel Community GitHub

3 Check Build Logs:

In Vercel dashboard, inspect build logs for detailed error information.

4 Contact Support:

If issues persist, contact Vercel support with your deployment logs.

ℹ️ Most deployment issues can be resolved by carefully checking paths, permissions, and configuration files.

This guide is based on common Vercel deployment issues and their solutions.

For your specific project "The Jemila Laundry", focus on the permission and path issues highlighted above.
